questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following is an example of large vessel vasculitis?
questions.explanation: Takayasu disease is an example of large vessel vasculitis.

questions.question:
Question 3: A 42-year-old man presented with complaints of fever, malaise, and weight loss. His lab 
investigations showed mild anemia, elevated ESR, and serology was positive for cANCA. 
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener’s granulomatosis) is the most likely diagnosis as it is 
associated with cANCA.

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following is not true about giant cell arteritis?

options.b: May lead to ischemic optic neuropathy

questions.explanation:
Giant cell arteritis is common in older women (>50 years of age). Giant cell arteritis is an inflammatory vasculitis of the large vessels, commonly seen in females 
over 50 years of age. It usually involves the temporal artery. It is characterized by fever, anemia, and headache. Depending on the artery involved, the patient 
may have tenderness over the affected artery, scalp pain, tongue and jaw claudication. Untreated 
patients may develop ischemic optic neuropathy. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated ESR and normochromic normocytic anemia. It shows 
good response to glucocorticoid therapy.

questions.question:
Question 5: A 65-year-old woman came with complaints of headache for the past 1-month. She also 
reported aching of the jaw during her meals. Over the last week, she has experienced episodes 
of painless visual loss which lasted for around 10 minutes. Which of the following is the best 
investigation for the diagnosis of her condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical presentation of headache, jaw claudication, and painless visual loss is suggestive 
of giant cell arteritis. The best investigation for the diagnosis of giant cell arteritis is temporal 
artery biopsy. Histopathology shows panarteritis with the presence of mononuclear cells and giant cells. The 
biopsy may not be positive in all patients due to patchy histologic findings. Since involvement of 
the vessel may be segmental, positive yield is increased by obtaining a biopsy segment of 3–5 cm 
together with serial sectioning of biopsy specimens. Note : According to the 21st edition of Harrison's Medicine, as involvement of the vessel may be 
segmental, getting a biopsy segment of 3–5 cm together with serial sectioning of biopsy specimens 
would help to increase a positive yield. And Robbin's 10th edition mentions that an adequate 
biopsy requires at least a 1-cm segment.

questions.question:
Question 6: A 50-year-old woman presents to your OPD with complaints of pain and stiffness of the 
shoulders which is worse in the morning. She works as a bus conductor and tells you that she 
has difficulty raising her shoulders to ring the bell. On examination, there is diffuse 
tenderness over the shoulders. Which of the following vasculitis is closely associated with her 
presentation?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical presentation of painful, tender, and stiff shoulders with restricted movement 
points toward a diagnosis of polymyalgia rheumatica, which is closely associated with giant cell 
arteritis. Polymyalgia rheumatica is characterized by pain and stiffness (worst in the morning) in the 
muscles of the neck, shoulder, back, hips, and thigh. On examination, diffuse tenderness is 
present without localization to any specific structures. Pain restricts the active range of motion 
but passive range of motion and muscle strength are normal. 455 
Sold by @itachibot ESR and CRP are typically elevated in polymyalgia rheumatica whereas creatine phosphokinase 
(CPK) lies within the normal range. It shows a good response to prednisone therapy.

questions.question:
Question 7: A 60-year-old woman presents with severe right-sided throbbing headache. She also gives 
history of pain and stiffness of the shoulders and hips. Her lab values show an ESR of 80 
mm/hr. What is the next best step in her management?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical presentation of headache and symptoms suggestive of polymyalgia rheumatica 
with raised ESR points towards a diagnosis of giant cell arteritis (GCA), for which the next best 
step is initiation of steroids (prednisone). Although temporal artery biopsy is the diagnostic investigation for GCA, it should not delay the 
initiation of steroids as it helps in reducing symptoms and preventing visual loss. The biopsy 
findings usually remain positive for at least 1 month after initiation of steroids. Newer drugs used in the treatment of giant cell arteritis are tocilizumab (anti-IL-6 receptor) and 
abatacept (CTLA4-Ig).

questions.question: Question 8: Which is the most common artery involved in Takayasu arteritis?
questions.explanation:
The most common artery involved in Takayasu arteritis is the subclavian artery. Patients present with pain, claudication, and weakness of the affected limb. The arterial pulse in 
the affected limb may be weak or absent. The order of arteries affected in Takayasu arteritis is subclavian artery > common carotid artery 
> abdominal aorta > renal artery > aortic arch = vertebral > coeliac axis > iliac > 
pulmonary > coronary artery.

questions.question:
Question 9: A 27-year-old woman presents to the hospital with fever, malaise, and arthralgia for a 
duration of 1 month. She also complains of pain, numbness, and weakness in her right arm, 
which has been increasing over the past 1 week. Clinical examination reveals weak radial 
pulses, and her laboratory investigations show elevated ESR. What is the most likely 
diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The above clinical features with a marked weakening of pulse in the upper extremities and 
laboratory findings of elevated ESR are suggestive of Takayasu arteritis. It is also known as 
pulseless disease. Takayasu arteritis is a systemic disease and may present with generalized and vascular symptoms. 
It commonly affects adolescents or young females. Generalized symptoms like fever, night sweats, 
weight loss, malaise, arthralgias, and anorexia may occur long before vascular symptoms. Vascular symptoms depend on the vessel involved: • Arch of the aorta and its branches: • Subclavian artery (most commonly affected) - It leads to weak pulses in the upper extremities. 
Hence, it is also known as pulseless disease. It may also lead to Raynaud’s phenomenon. • Carotid arteries- It leads to weak pulses, blindness, and neurological deficits. • Aortic arch- It may lead to congestive heart failure. 456 
Sold by @itachibot • Abdominal aorta, celiac axis, and superior mesenteric artery - leads to abdominal pain, nausea, 
and vomiting • Iliac vessels - leads to claudication of the legs • Renal arteries - leads to systemic hypertension • Pulmonary artery - leads to pulmonary hypertension • Coronary arteries (least commonly affected) - lead to myocardial infarction Investigations: • Laboratory tests reveal an elevated ESR level, anemia, and elevated immunoglobulin levels. • Arteriography is done as a confirmatory test. Treatment includes glucocorticoid therapy, methotrexate, immunotherapy with anti-TNF agents, 
and surgery.

questions.question:
Question 10: In a patient with suspected Behcet's disease which of the following tests can be used to 
confirm the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Pathergy test can be used for confirming Behcet's disease. It is a nonspecific inflammatory skin 
reaction to scratch or intradermal saline injection and is a specific manifestation. The diagnostic criteria in Behcet's syndrome are the presence of recurrent oral ulcerations plus 
two of the following findings: • Recurrent genital ulcerations • Ocular lesions • Skin lesions • Positive pathergy test Option A: Foshay test is used in cat-scratch disease. Option B: Tzanck test is used to diagnose herpes infection. Option D: The cardiolipin antibody test is used to detect antiphospholipid antibodies.

Question 11: 451 
Sold by @itachibot A 35-year-old woman presented with recurrent oral and genital ulcerations. An inflammatory 
skin reaction was observed after intradermal administration of normal saline. Which of the 
following statements is incorrect about her condition?

options.b: Associated with painless scarring oral ulcers

questions.explanation:
Recurrent oral and genital ulcerations with a positive pathergy test are suggestive of Behcet's 
syndrome. It is associated with oral ulcers that are painful and heal without scarring. Behcet's syndrome usually affects young individuals and is associated with HLA-B51 
and anti-Saccharomyces cerevisiae antibodies. The clinical features of Behcet's syndrome include: • Oral ulcers - painful, non-scarring • Genital ulcers - painful, scarring • Ocular involvement - scarring and bilateral panuveitis 457 
Sold by @itachibot • Skin involvement - folliculitis, acne-like rashes, erythema nodosum, and pyoderma gangrenosum • Arthritis and peripheral vein thrombosis

questions.question: Question 12: Which of the following is a medium vessel vasculitis?
questions.explanation: Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) is a medium vessel vasculitis.

questions.question:
Question 13: A 47-year-old man presented to the hospital with the findings shown in the image below. He 
also complained of pain in the upper and lower limbs. On examination, his BP was 160/100 
mmHg and his peripheral pulses were palpable. Serology was negative for ANCA. What is the 
most probable diagnosis? 452 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The most probable diagnosis is polyarteritis nodosa. The image shows the gangrene of the fingers. The presence of myalgia, the involvement of 
cutaneous vessels (gangrene with palpable peripheral pulses), renal vessels causing hypertension 
and serology negative for ANCA make polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) the most probable diagnosis. Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) is necrotizing arteritis of the medium-sized blood vessels. It can affect 
the skin, peripheral nerves, renal vessels, mesenteric vessels, heart, and brain. Lungs are usually 
spared in PAN. The disease initially starts with non-specific symptoms like fever, malaise, arthralgia, and myalgia. 
Later, depending on the artery involved, patients may develop the following symptoms: • Skin findings - ulcers, digital gangrene, and livedo reticularis • Renal arteries - hypertension and renal failure • Mesenteric arteries - abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, bleeding, and a bowel perforation Other options: 1) Takayasu arteritis- It is a large vessel vasculitis. Also known as pulseless disease as it may be 
associated with weak upper extremity pulses. 2) Microscopic polyangiitis- It is a small vessel vasculitis. It is positive for p-ANCA. Presentation is 
similar to granulomatosis with polyangiitis but without upper airway involvement. 3) Cryoglobulinemic vasculitis- It is frequently associated with hepatitis C. Circulating 
cryoglubulins and rheumatoid factor can be found in blood. Most common clinical manifestations 
are cutaneous vasculitis, peripheral neuropathy, glomerulonephritis and arthritis.

questions.question:
Question 14: In a patient diagnosed with polyarteritis nodosa which of the following arteries are 
characteristically spared?
questions.explanation:
Pulmonary arteries are characteristically spared in polyarteritis nodosa (PAN). PAN mainly 
involves renal and visceral arteries. Histopathology of the involved arteries usually shows the following findings: • Transmural necrotizing vasculitis of the arteries and adjacent veins. Venules are spared. • Renal arteries - arteritis without glomerulonephritis 458 
Sold by @itachibot • Fibrinoid necrosis • Absence of granuloma and eosinophilia

questions.question: Question 15: Which of the following is true about polyarteritis nodosa?
questions.explanation:
One-third of polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) cases are associated with Hepatitis B. Other options: Option A: Polyarteritis nodosa is a systemic vasculitis which is associated with necrotizing 
inflammation of small and medium-sized muscular arteries. Option B: Patients show hypergammaglobulinemia. Option C: PAN is rarely associated with ANCA positivity. There is no serological test for PAN. 
Most patients exhibit an elevated leukocyte count with a predominance of neutrophils. PAN is usually seen in young adults, characterized by rapidly accelerating hypertension, 
abdominal pain, bloody stools, myalgias, and peripheral neuropathy. Arterial inflammation is segmental, necrotizing, and transmural, leading to aneurysms and 
thrombosis. The involved vessels are typically found at arterial bifurcations, spreading to veins but sparing 
venules. The most commonly affected organs are the kidney, heart, liver, and gastrointestinal 
tract, in that order. Pulmonary arteries are not involved. Inadequate blood flow leads to ischemia, 
ulcers, infarcts, atrophy, or hemorrhage. Diagnosis relies on histopathological findings from organ biopsies or the demonstration of 
aneurysms in small to medium-sized arteries of the renal, hepatic, and visceral vasculature. Untreated PAN has an extremely poor prognosis, with a 5-year survival rate of only 10 to 20%. 
Common causes of death include gastrointestinal complications, such as bowel infarcts and 
perforation, as well as cardiovascular issues. Timely treatment is vital for improved outcomes. Combining prednisone and cyclophosphamide has shown significant benefits in survival rates. 
Glucocorticoids alone may be sufficient for milder cases. In PAN cases associated with hepatitis B 
or C, antiviral therapy is combined with glucocorticoids and plasma exchange. Managing 
hypertension effectively can help reduce vascular complications. Despite successful treatment, 
relapses occur in approximately 10-20% of patients. A histopathological image of PAN showing necrotizing transmural inflammation is given below: 459

questions.question: Question 16: What is the most common cause of vasculitis in children in India?
questions.explanation:
The most common cause of vasculitis in children in India is Kawasaki disease. Kawasaki disease has a higher incidence in children in the Indian subcontinent. The most common vasculitis worldwide is Henoch-Schonlein purpura, whereas in the Indian 
subcontinent and other Asian countries the most common vasculitis is Kawasaki disease. 460 
Sold by @itachibot Small vessel vasculitis
